Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story: The store was quiet that afternoon, the kind of slow where I could hear the hum of the fridge behind the counter. I was scanning groceries for Mrs. Patel when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a text from my little brother: “Hey, can I come hang out with you and your friends after your shift?” I knew he’d been feeling left out lately, and I’d promised myself I’d try harder to include him. But as I glanced at the line, I saw my manager watching from the office window. I was supposed to keep my phone away and focus on the register, making sure every item scanned right and every receipt was perfect. My brother’s message tugged at me, reminding me of the kind of sister I wanted to be—someone he could count on. But the weight of my job’s expectations pressed down, too. I could feel my heart beating faster, torn between replying to him right away or ignoring the message until my break, knowing either choice would let someone down.
